I always use the lidocaine cream 1-2 hrs prior to numb the area. And when I happen to not dab enough in there, I feel a quick pinch and it's over with within 2 seconds. Good luck with your port!

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 04:20AM Kaelia wrote: Renae, I have had my moments too when I cried and asked the same questions as you to God. I learned to keep my focus on God and trust that he will carry me through this. The things that I have control over are what I do my best to work on: my mental health, my spiritual health and staying proactive in understanding and participating in that cancer care. I realize I don't have any control over the outcome of this sickness and I leave that to God. At the end of the day, I don't think it's God's plan for anyone to have cancer.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 01:24PM Kaelia wrote: I have liver mets; found 3 masses ( 2 small and 1 larger). Doc had told me it's common to have spots on the liver and it could be nothing, such as hemangiomas like Coolbreeze mentioned. The MRI was inconclusive so they ordered a biopsy came back confirming mets. I would say definitely ask your doctor for more testing. Good luck and keep us informed!

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2013 04:08PM Kaelia wrote: Congrats for being NED Fugimama! I recently had a bmx with temporary tissue expanders put in. I am now going through rads and once my skin heals; the plan is to have my final reconstruction. I am looking so looking forward to that! Diep was my first choice but after weighing my options (not enough of my own tissue for both breasts so it would have been for one breast only and I would have had an implant in the other one) I choose implants. I just have to decide what type of implants. If you want reconstruction, go for it.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2012 09:26PM Kaelia wrote: 5LUVBUGS, my nails are turning grey and blue at the cuticle too, just like Eleni I keep them short and paint them every now and them to keep the nails strongs. So I am going to bed after this post; to make it for my neulasta shot in the morning then work. My onc offered me Ambien, I am thinking of taking his offer as much as I am a partisan od the least medication necessary but this lack is getting to me :( TXJUNEBUG that's awesome to hear that your boss is accomodating you in that way. Mine is pretty cool too, called me today to check on me after chemo and offer me some support- told me to stay at home tomorrow also if needed. Thinking of you all Ladies and hoping for the best through this journey for everyone :)

Those of you who have done it and/or know about it, could you tell how you have benefited from it? Thanks! Posts.Title: Stage IV, single and dating? Any advice? Kaelia Kaelia

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2012 05:18AM Kaelia wrote: I am truly sorry to hear about your sister. I, myself was diagnosed just a couple of weeks ago at 34 years old. I went from my world turned upside down and the initial shock of "I cannot believe this is happening" to "what can I do to improve my quality of life and not let this take over my everyday life". The ladies on this board are amazing and full of resources. I am not in the Nyc area but I came across some info for your area. Cancercare.org offers help with cost of transportation, child care, home care and free meals delivered (Magnolia free meals at home) to metastatic bc patients. I also found that some the local churches will have a support network in place for those fighting cancer; can offer advice or connect you to other women going through the same thing for tips. Sending hugs and prayers :)
Posts.Title: ANYONE DIAGNOSED WITH STAGE IV IN EARLY TO MID 30s? lmyna2006 Kaelia

Posts.Content: May 3, 2014 12:14AM Kaelia wrote: Mary, you'll see your onc a lot more than a lot of people so you probably want to have one that you can connect with and with whom you feel comfortable. When you feel the time is right for you, don't hesitate to switch onc. My onc has met my family, friends; I've shared pictures and told him about my fears, hopes and dreams. And he's in tune with me about my treatment. I am on chemo for life too and it's possible to have good QOL like many of us here while in treatment. You are in my thoughts. ~ hugs
